linkTarget.anchoringText: The absence of traditional signs of PMS work is caused mainly by low current and accumulated replacement ratio on the early stages of injection (Fig. 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Current and accumulated replacement ratios within PMS forming cluster

formatted-caption.caption-text: Current and accumulated replacement ratios within PMS forming cluster

linkTarget.anchoringText: This experiment also proved low efficiency of surface water injection. Actually from the first days of an experiment dramatical downhole and wellhead pressure raise was observed, along with injection rate decrease (fig. 2). Further investigations showed that effective permeability near the well dropped to non-reservoir values, practically causing injection to stop. It makes it impossible to increase replacement ratio. Wellhead pressure increase was not used to prevent development of auto-fractures.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Main parameters of pilot well after switching to injection. Left axis shows injection rates (blue points, m3/day) and wellhead pressure (yellow points, atm). Right axis shows downhole pressure (red points, atm), according to downhole gauge

formatted-caption.caption-text: Main parameters of pilot well after switching to injection. Left axis shows injection rates (blue points, m3/day) and wellhead pressure (yellow points, atm). Right axis shows downhole pressure (red points, atm), according to downhole gauge

linkTarget.anchoringText: Concept model is shown on Fig.3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Concept model of injection from upper waterbed with reversed ESP

formatted-caption.caption-text: Concept model of injection from upper waterbed with reversed ESP

linkTarget.anchoringText: PMS effectiveness has been decided to estimate with analysis of producers behavior within every injection cluster. All the dynamic data of producers was taken for the analysis, such as bottomhole pressure, daily rates and water-cut during all working period (fig. 4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Downhole pressure and rate during the working period. Upper part of the graph shows bottomhole pressure from well launch (atm, recalculated to WOC). Lower part shows rate (m3/day). Water-cut stays the same all the working period

formatted-caption.caption-text: Downhole pressure and rate during the working period. Upper part of the graph shows bottomhole pressure from well launch (atm, recalculated to WOC). Lower part shows rate (m3/day). Water-cut stays the same all the working period

linkTarget.anchoringText: Then extended transient analysis was performed with use of all pressure and rate measurements, allowing to define flow regimes, caused by drainage area borders and well interference. An example of this analysis is shown on fig. 5.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: An example of extended log-log analysis with marked flow regimes. Green points on the graph are absolute pressure drop (P-P0), red points – pressure derivative. Red and black lines are model pressure and pressure derivative curves, matching the actual data. Tangent lines of flow regimes are shown in interference period. Red line with slope = 1 is WBS. Bright green lines with slope = 1/2 is linear flow to the fracture. Blue line with zero slope is pseudo radial flow, orange line is interference with nearby producer regime – (slope = 1/2), green line – constant pressure boundaries (slope = –1/2). X axis shows time

formatted-caption.caption-text: An example of extended log-log analysis with marked flow regimes. Green points on the graph are absolute pressure drop (P-P0), red points – pressure derivative. Red and black lines are model pressure and pressure derivative curves, matching the actual data. Tangent lines of flow regimes are shown in interference period. Red line with slope = 1 is WBS. Bright green lines with slope = 1/2 is linear flow to the fracture. Blue line with zero slope is pseudo radial flow, orange line is interference with nearby producer regime – (slope = 1/2), green line – constant pressure boundaries (slope = –1/2). X axis shows time

linkTarget.anchoringText: Most of the wells analyzed, allegedly influenced by injection, did not show robust derivative slope, meaning constant boundaries (–1/2). An example of such derivative behavior is presented on fig. 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: An example of extended log-log analysis with marked flow regimes. Green points on the graph are absolute pressure drop (P-P0), red points – pressure derivative. Red and black lines are model pressure and pressure derivative curves, matching the actual data. Tangent lines of flow regimes are shown in interference period. Red line with slope = 1 is WBS. Bright green lines with slope = 1/2 is linear flow to the fracture. Bright blue line with zero slope is pseudo radial flow, blue line is interference with nearby producer regime – (slope = 1), orange line – slope reduction of interference regime (slope = 1/2). X axis shows time

formatted-caption.caption-text: An example of extended log-log analysis with marked flow regimes. Green points on the graph are absolute pressure drop (P-P0), red points – pressure derivative. Red and black lines are model pressure and pressure derivative curves, matching the actual data. Tangent lines of flow regimes are shown in interference period. Red line with slope = 1 is WBS. Bright green lines with slope = 1/2 is linear flow to the fracture. Bright blue line with zero slope is pseudo radial flow, blue line is interference with nearby producer regime – (slope = 1), orange line – slope reduction of interference regime (slope = 1/2). X axis shows time

linkTarget.anchoringText: History matching shows significant deviation of model data from the actual data in case of stable nearby wells behavior. In opposite, taking into account an effect of injection makes a perfect match on both pressure and production. The match of actual and model data of one of producing wells in both variants are shown on fig. 7 and 8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Actual and model data match with no PMS influence. Upper part of the graph shows rate and accumulated rate (orange points – actual accumulated rate [m3], khaki points – actual rate[m3/day], red lines – model curves, based on actual pressure). Lower part of the graph shows pressure and average drainage area pressure (green points – actual pressure [atm], red line – model curve, based on actual rate, brown line – average drainage area pressure)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Actual and model data match with no PMS influence. Upper part of the graph shows rate and accumulated rate (orange points – actual accumulated rate [m3], khaki points – actual rate[m3/day], red lines – model curves, based on actual pressure). Lower part of the graph shows pressure and average drainage area pressure (green points – actual pressure [atm], red line – model curve, based on actual rate, brown line – average drainage area pressure)

linkTarget.anchoringText: History matching shows significant deviation of model data from the actual data in case of stable nearby wells behavior. In opposite, taking into account an effect of injection makes a perfect match on both pressure and production. The match of actual and model data of one of producing wells in both variants are shown on fig. 7 and 8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Actual and model data match with PMS influence. Upper part of the graph shows rate and accumulated rate (orange points – actual accumulated rate [m3], khaki points – actual rate[m3/day], red lines – model curves, based on actual pressure). Lower part of the graph shows pressure (green points – actual pressure [atm], red line – model curve, based on actual rate)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Actual and model data match with PMS influence. Upper part of the graph shows rate and accumulated rate (orange points – actual accumulated rate [m3], khaki points – actual rate[m3/day], red lines – model curves, based on actual pressure). Lower part of the graph shows pressure (green points – actual pressure [atm], red line – model curve, based on actual rate)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Of course, the group of analyzed wells contained wells, not influenced by injection at all, despite they are close to injection wells. An example of log-log analysis of one of such wells if shown on fig.9, representing typical pressure derivative behavior in case of closed boundary model, i.e. depletion mode. In different cases, it was caused by long distance to injector or geologic boundaries effects, which if quite logical and excludes false influence conclusions on previous well groups.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: An example of extended log-log analysis with marked flow regimes. Green points on the graph are absolute pressure drop (P-P0), red points – pressure derivative. Red and black lines are model pressure and pressure derivative curves, matching the actual data. Tangent lines of flow regimes are shown in interference period. Bright green lines with slope = 1/2 is linear flow to the fracture. Bright blue line with zero slope is pseudo radial flow, orange line is interference with nearby producer regime – (slope = 1/2), blue line – depletion mode (slope = 1/2). X axis shows time

formatted-caption.caption-text: An example of extended log-log analysis with marked flow regimes. Green points on the graph are absolute pressure drop (P-P0), red points – pressure derivative. Red and black lines are model pressure and pressure derivative curves, matching the actual data. Tangent lines of flow regimes are shown in interference period. Bright green lines with slope = 1/2 is linear flow to the fracture. Bright blue line with zero slope is pseudo radial flow, orange line is interference with nearby producer regime – (slope = 1/2), blue line – depletion mode (slope = 1/2). X axis shows time

linkTarget.anchoringText: One of the analyzed clusters is shown on fig. 10 with marks of influence from switching a x20P well to injection.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Pilot injection cluster on a pressure + current rate map fragment. Influenced wells are marked with blue circle; red circles mark the wells with no influence

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pilot injection cluster on a pressure + current rate map fragment. Influenced wells are marked with blue circle; red circles mark the wells with no influence

linkTarget.anchoringText: Then for all the wells, proved to be influenced by PMS, production forecast was performed excluding this influence (fig. 11).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Production forecast with no respect to injection influence. Upper part of the graph shows rate and accumulated rate (orange points – actual accumulated rate [m3], khaki points – actual rate[m3/day], red lines – model curves, based on actual pressure, stable BHP = 47 atm was used in forecast). Lower part of the graph shows pressure (green points – actual pressure [atm], red line – model curve, based on actual rate)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production forecast with no respect to injection influence. Upper part of the graph shows rate and accumulated rate (orange points – actual accumulated rate [m3], khaki points – actual rate[m3/day], red lines – model curves, based on actual pressure, stable BHP = 47 atm was used in forecast). Lower part of the graph shows pressure (green points – actual pressure [atm], red line – model curve, based on actual rate)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Then forecast data was compared with actual production data since PMS influence start (fig.12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of production forecast with no respect to PMS influence and the actual production, with accumulated additional production. Blue curve – monthly production, red curve – monthly production forecast with no PMS, green curve – accumulated additional production

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of production forecast with no respect to PMS influence and the actual production, with accumulated additional production. Blue curve – monthly production, red curve – monthly production forecast with no PMS, green curve – accumulated additional production
